exercise: Work
The amount of matter in an object, usually measured in kilograms (kg).
Energy
The rate of change of velocity of an object, often expressed in meters per second squared (m/s²).
Kinetic Energy
The potential energy of an object based on its height and mass in a gravitational field, calculated as \( PE = mgh \).
Potential Energy
The measure of how far an object has moved in a specific direction, typically measured in meters (m).
Work-Energy Principle
The amount of energy transferred when a force acts on an object and causes it to move, calculated as \( W = F \cdot d \cdot \cos(\theta) \).
Force
The energy an object possesses due to its motion, calculated using the formula \( KE = \frac{1}{2} mv^2 \).
Distance
The measurement of an object's elevation above a reference point, generally measured in meters (m).
Magnitude
The speed of an object in a given direction, measured in meters per second (m/s).
Acceleration
The energy held by an object because of its position or configuration, typically gravitational potential energy given by the formula \( PE = mgh \).
Velocity
The capacity to perform work, existing in various forms such as kinetic energy and potential energy, measured in joules (J).
Mass
The size or quantity of a physical quantity, such as force or energy.
Height
An interaction that causes an object to accelerate, measured in newtons (N).
Gravitational Potential Energy
The principle stating that the work done on an object is equal to the change in its energy, expressed as \( W = \Delta KE \).

solution.Work: The amount of energy transferred when a force acts on an object and causes it to move, calculated as \( W = F \cdot d \cdot \cos(\theta) \).
solution.Energy: The capacity to perform work, existing in various forms such as kinetic energy and potential energy, measured in joules (J).
solution.Kinetic Energy: The energy an object possesses due to its motion, calculated using the formula \( KE = \frac{1}{2} mv^2 \).
solution.Potential Energy: The energy held by an object because of its position or configuration, typically gravitational potential energy given by the formula \( PE = mgh \).
solution.Work-Energy Principle: The principle stating that the work done on an object is equal to the change in its energy, expressed as \( W = \Delta KE \).
solution.Force: An interaction that causes an object to accelerate, measured in newtons (N).
solution.Distance: The measure of how far an object has moved in a specific direction, typically measured in meters (m).
solution.Magnitude: The size or quantity of a physical quantity, such as force or energy.
solution.Acceleration: The rate of change of velocity of an object, often expressed in meters per second squared (m/s²).
solution.Velocity: The speed of an object in a given direction, measured in meters per second (m/s).
solution.Mass: The amount of matter in an object, usually measured in kilograms (kg).
solution.Height: The measurement of an object's elevation above a reference point, generally measured in meters (m).
solution.Gravitational Potential Energy: The potential energy of an object based on its height and mass in a gravitational field, calculated as \( PE = mgh \).
